section.name: About this Guide
section.p: This guide is the reference for the Velocity Template Language (VTL). For more information, please also refer to the Velocity User Guide.

section.name: References

ul.li: Regular Notation with Parameter List: $page.setTitle( "My Home Page" )

section.p: VTL Properties can be used as a shorthand notation for VTL Methods that take get and set. Either $object.getMethod() or $object.setMethod() can be abbreviated as $object.Method. It is generally preferable to use a Property when available. The main difference between Properties and Methods is that you can specify a parameter list to a Method.

subsection.name: #set - Establishes the value of a reference

ul.li: $ref - The LHS of the assignment must be a variable reference or a property reference.
arg - The RHS of the assignment, arg is parsed if enclosed in double quotes, and not parsed if enclosed in single quotes. If the RHS evaluates to null, it is not assigned to the LHS.

subsection.name: #if/#elseif/#else - Output conditional on truth of statements

ul.li: condition - If a boolean, considered true if it has a true false; if not a boolean, considered true if not null.

ol.li: The == operator can be used to compare numbers, strings, objects of the same class, or objects of different classes. In the last case (when objects are of different classes), the toString() method is called on each object and the resulting Strings are compared.
You can also use brackets to delimit directives. This is especially useful when text immediately follows an #else directive.

subsection.name: #foreach - Loops through a list of objects

ul.li: $ref - The first variable reference is the item.
arg - May be one of the following: a reference to a list (i.e. object array, collection, or map), an array list, or the range operator.
statement - What is output each time Velocity finds a valid item in the list denoted above as arg. This output is any valid VTL and is rendered each iteration of the loop.

subsection.name: #include - Renders local file(s) that are not parsed by Velocity

ul.li: arg - Refers to a valid file under TEMPLATE_ROOT.

subsection.name: #parse - Renders a local template that is parsed by Velocity

ul.li: arg - Refers to a template under TEMPLATE_ROOT.

subsection.p: Recursion permitted. See parse_directive.maxdepth in velocity.properties to change from parse depth. (The default parse depth is 10.)

subsection.name: #stop - Stops the template engine
subsection.p: This will stop execution of the current template. This is good for debugging a template.

subsection.name: #break - Stops the current directive
subsection.p: This will break execution of the current content directive. This is good for exiting a #foreach loop early, but also works in other scopes. You can even pass the scope control reference for a specific outer scope to break execution of all scopes outward to the specified one.

subsection.name: #evaluate - Dynamically evaluates a string or reference

ul.li: arg - String literal or reference to be dynamically evaluated.

subsection.name: #define - Assigns a block of VTL to a reference

ul.li: $ref - Reference that is assigned the VTL block as a value.
statement - Statement that is assigned to the reference.

subsection.name: #macro - Allows users to define a Velocimacro (VM), a repeated segment of a VTL template, as required
subsection.p: # [ { ] macro [ } ] ( vmname $arg1 [ $arg2 $arg3 ... $argn ] ) [ VM VTL code... ] # [ { ] end [ } ]

ul.li: vmname - Name used to call the VM (#vmname)
$arg1 $arg2 [ ... ] - Arguments to the VM. There can be any number of arguments, but the number used at invocation must match the number specified in the definition.
[ VM VTL code... ] - Any valid VTL code, anything you can put into a template, can be put into a VM.

subsection.p: Once defined, the VM is used like any other VTL directive in a template.

Except, that when you wish to call a VM with a body, then you must prefix the name of the VM with @. The content of that body may be referenced in the macro definition via $!bodyContent as many or few times as you like.

ol.li: Inline: found in regular templates, only usable when velocimacro.permissions.allowInline=true in velocity.properties.

section.name: Comments
section.p: Comments are not rendered at runtime.

p.strong:
#*
This is a multiline comment.
This is the second line
*#

section.name: Unparsed Content
section.p: Unparsed content is rendered at runtime, but is not parsed or interpreted.

p.strong:
#[[
This has invalid syntax that would normally need "poor man's escaping" like:
#define()
${blah
]]#
